awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Multinational Corporation Behavior in Time of War
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the extent to which countries can successfully wield economic (dis-)integration as a foreign policy tool. That is, when and why can countries use economic statecraft to pressure commercial firms to make investments consistent with their foreign policy interests? The project will examine the universe of foreign-owned firms in one aggressor state, and researchers will use multilingual media reports, corporate press releases, and other textual sources to document the behavior of MNCs toward the aggressor state. Findings from this project will provide new insights into the relative success of home countries' economic statecraft strategies against an aggressor nation under conditions of deep economic globalization. This project will also benefit both graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds through hands-on training and practical experience with data management and analysis.

This project examines multinational corporation (MNC) responses to a common host country political shock, while making clear the depths of heterogeneity in MNC behavior, even and especially in light of remarkably strong economic sanctions. The theory incorporates not only host but also home country political risk, and the effects of political risk on decision-making at entry and exit, which addresses serious lacunae in the ability of the literature to explain disruptions in foreign direct investment (FDI) due to aggressive war. The project will generate a public, replicable dataset covering the universe of MNCs operating in a nation-state that initiated an aggressive war. The researchers will document firm-level behavior following the invasion, based on an analysis of a multilingual corpus of media reports, corporate press releases, and related textual sources. A combined theoretical and empirical goal of this project is to identify the relevance of economic statecraft and home country political interests – whether favoring divestment or otherwise – to MNC decision-making under conditions of contemporary economic globalization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine beginning 24 February 2022, foreign-owned multinational corporations (MNCs) with operations in Russia found themselves in a host state that had initiated a conventional interstate war – an unprecedented shock in the modern era of economic globalization. This shock allows us to consider MNC behavior in times of war, and particularly the impact of several sets of theoretically-grounded predictions that scholars have not previously been able to rigorously test. In particular, we explore whether MNCs are more likely to exit in the context of war if the event causes a negative shock to the relations between their home state and the host state; if the MNC faces non-state backlash from consumers, activists, and/or shareholders; or if the specificity of the MNCs’ assets make them more difficult to either relocate abroad or resell. Further, by focusing on exit as a transaction – one in which the MNC aims to maximize value recovered from its investments – we also test predictions regarding the ease with which the MNC can find buyers.

In terms of intellectual merit and broader impact, our data collection is notable:

  •  We generate a novel dataset of the over 48,000 MNCs operating in Russia as of the end of calendar year 2021, originating from 135 home jurisdictions. This allows us to make credible inferences based on the population of MNCs in Russia, and it provides a first of its kind baseline for the population of MNCs in a deeply integrated host state that can be leveraged by future scholars.
  • We use company registration data and record-keeping to generate novel measures of exit-based ownership changes. This allows us to make defensible statements about actual behaviors undertaken by MNCs, which is not otherwise possible with news-based data collection efforts or qualitative efforts such as interviews with executives. We also document and take into account disruptions to Russian record-keeping in the months after the full-scale invasion, and as a result base our analysis on credible record-keeping as of the 18-month post-invasion mark.
  • We collect and compile results and methodologies of 12 “name and shame” efforts undertaken by activists and scholars with normative motivations. We match entries on those lists to about 3,000 unique MNCs in the full dataset. We can therefore probe relationships between those efforts and MNC behavior.
  • We generate a novel, plausibly exogenous measure of strategic industries in Russia, linked back to Russian efforts around the 2008 financial crisis. Although China has specific lists of strategic industries, other states generally do not, so this Russian measure will be useful in itself and as a methodological foundation upon which measures in other national contexts can build.
  • We compile and analyze the set of laws and decrees the Russian state has instituted with regard to foreign investment since the invasion, which target MNCs from home states that Russia has deemed “unfriendly.”  

In terms of intellectual merit and broader impact, our preliminary results are also notable:

  • In our primary working paper, we find that as of 18-months post-invasion, 38 percent of MNCs have undergone ownership changes.
  • We find nuanced results that predict variation in MNC ownership changes beyond whether or not the MNCs’ home state has participated in economic sanctions against Russia. For example, covariates measuring non-state backlash to continuing Russian operations predict exit, for MNCs from sanctioning states and for MNCs from other jurisdictions.
  • One of the most important predictors of exit is that the MNC already had a controlling Russian owner. Relatedly, we confirm that 7 percent of MNCs are continuing operations as domestic Russian companies; we intend to do further work to understand the “buy” side of transactions when MNCs might have been acquired by Russian owners and thus dissolved as independent entities. These results are of broader interest to scholars and practitioners concerned with the consequences of leveraging MNCs as a tool of economic statecraft.

 This research has been presented to audiences at the International Political Economy Society (2023), the International Studies Association (2023), the American Political Science Association (2023), and in more informal settings with scholars of law, business, and economics, as well as political science and international relations. We are preparing a core manuscript for submission and intend to pursue several related projects in future work. We have also been able to support a variety of graduate and undergraduate student researchers at University of Texas at Austin and Penn State in political science, economics, computer science, and business, who have directly gained a variety of data cleaning and project management skills and indirectly used their participation as a springboard for related individual projects.
